text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with grilled shrimp Louie that's
right out of all the composed salads
named after men I'd have to say the
Louie is my favorite
sorry celery Victor but it's true and
while the delicious dressing I'm about
to show you is usually used to make a
crab Louie I think this grilled shrimp
version is even better and of course as
usual I can prove nothing so I guess
you'll have to make this and try both
and see what you think but anyway let's
go ahead and begin with the star of the
show our Louie dressing and that's going
to start by adding a whole bunch of
mayonnaise to a mixing bowl and then to
that we're supposed to add some chili
sauce but we're not going to we're
actually going to do some ketchup
instead since bottle chili sauce is
nothing more than ketchup that's been
kicked up with a little extra sugar and
spices so we're going to do is just sort
of make our own in this bowl from
scratch so we will add some ketchup
followed by some creme fraiche and by
the way the original recipe calls for
heavy cream instead which was whipped
and sort of folded into the dressing at
the end and I have had it that way and
it's not bad but I really do prefer the
creme fraiche or sour cream if you want
okay so that's basically the base for
our dressing and then to that we're
going to add a little additional acidity
in the form of freshly squeezed lemon
juice as well as a little bit of apple
cider vinegar and by the way check it
out today's video comes with free
tickets to the gun show you're welcome
ladies and then to balance that out
we'll add a little touch of brown sugar
followed by a spoon of paprika and then
we definitely want a little touch of
salt
as well as some pepper this time in the
form of cayenne and if you want a lot of
people like to add a few dashes of hot
sauce instead of the cayenne or in
addition to but of course that kind of
things up to you you are the king of
this Louie but either way I do think
this needs a little bit of heat to it
and then we'll go ahead and finish this
up with a few dashes of Worcestershire
sauce as well as a little bit of
vegetation so we'll toss in some finely
minced green onions as well as some
freshly chopped Italian parsley and
that's going to be it for our Louie
dressing ingredients so let's go ahead
and grab a whisk and give that a mix and
you might think as soon as all that's
combined your dressing is done but it's
really not because what we really want
to do is wrap this up and pop in the
fridge for at least a few hours so the
dressing can as they say mature
which simply means giving those
ingredients time to meld together plus
and maybe even more importantly we want
to serve this dressing very cold so
that's the temperature we need to taste
it at before we taste and adjust for
seasoning so sure technically you can
use this as soon as it's mixed but as I
said I highly recommend wrapping this up
and pop it in the fridge for a few hours
until thoroughly thoroughly chilled
which works out nice time management
wise because that gives us time to prep
and grill our shrimp and there they are
I peeled and deveined shrimp and to prep
these for the grill what we'll do is
drizzle over a little bit of olive oil
as well as the freshly squeezed juice of
a half a lemon and then we'll season
that up with just a little touch of
smoked paprika not really even enough to
register on the palate but just that
little bits going to elevate the
sweetness and the smokiness of the
shrimp and it will also do a little bit
of salt and that's it we will take our
spatula and give that a thorough but
gentle mixing until all those shrimp are
evenly coated at which point we can grab
our tongs and head out to the grill or
at least that's what I'm calling it and
we will place a shrimp down over a very
hot charcoal fire and cook those for
about two minutes per side of course
your times may vary depending on how big
your shrimp are I believe the ones I'm
using are the 21 to 25 shrimp per pound
size so if you're using something
similar a couple minutes per side should
be plenty and by the way if you're
wondering why we left those tails on
even though we're going to use these in
a salad that's because believe it or not
those are going to provide a ton of
flavor as we grill these there's
something that happens when that shell
chars a little bit and it seems to
permeate the meat of the shrimp with a
little extra smokiness and sweetness I
can't really explain it that well but I
know it's true so I'll usually leave
those tails on and either serve it like
that or peel them off right before we
put them on the salad but anyway like I
said we're going to grill those for a
couple minutes per side or until done
and I know people say you should only
turn stuff once on the grill and not to
play with your food but I'd like to so I
do
and yes partially out of spite but I do
enjoy being able to turn those more than
once and I've not had a complaint yet
and then once we've determined those
have cooked long enough we'll pull them
off the grill and we will head inside
where we have to make some decisions we
can certainly serve these on our salad
warm like this or if we want we can let
them cool and then chill them in the
fridge and serve them cold which by the
way is how I'm going to do them
but not before ie one in the business we
call that quality control and man was
that good believe me it was very
tempting to just start dipping these in
our dressing and eat them like popcorn
but anyway like I said Amanda Chili's
before I serve them but either way our
shrimp are ready our dressings been made
and chilled and we are ready to move on
to final production so let's pull our
Louis dressing out because we definitely
want to give it a taste for seasoning
before we serve it and I'm happy to
report not only was it beautiful to look
at but it tasted just right so I didn't
have to adjust and I was able to move on
to plating and for your classic Louie
you're going to need some kind of bed of
lettuce
traditionally iceberg is used but that
stuff's just so boring in nondescript so
instead I like to use some chopped up
hearts of romaine and then we definitely
also want some tomato in this and I'm
officially recommending the cherry
variety here I mean you could just wedge
up some regular Tomatoes if you want but
cherry tomatoes are so much sweeter and
look so much better however other than
that there's no real advantage
so we'll do a generous scattering of
cherry tomatoes followed by some
gorgeous creamy avocado which I do not
believe was included in the classic
Louie but I'm definitely going to use
them on mine and the next up we will add
some hard-boiled egg which is an
absolutely mandatory ingredient although
I'm not actually using hard-boiled eggs
I'm using what I call soft hard-boiled
eggs which I am tempted to show you how
to make since they're just like a
hard-boiled egg but the yolk is a little
softer and creamier but anyway we
definitely want to include some egg here
which is you can probably see I did
season up with some salt and freshly
ground black pepper and then before we
add our shrimp we want to put our
dressing down first and this is
old-school classic Louie technique
because the theory is you don't want the
dressing covering your seafood so
whether you're using crab or shrimp or
whatever we ladle the dressing down
first and then place the seafood over
the top so that's what I did
so we'll toss on whatever we think is
the appropriate amount of shrimp and
then last but not least I finish that
off a little bit of sliced green onion
which looked pretty good but then I
realized I couldn't see my dressing so
basically I said to heck with tradition
and I added a little bit of dressing
over the top with a few more green
onions which I think looked a lot better
although it wasn't quite
so I did a little shake of cayenne and
finally I was able to say that's it our
grilled shrimp Louie has done so I'm
gonna grab a fork and dig right in and
the beauty of this Louie dressing is
it's good on everything okay just
amazing with the shrimp
but equally amazing with the avocado and
the egg and the tomato etc so just a
brilliant all-purpose salad dressing and
yes as I said at the beginning this is
traditionally served with crab but since
we're right in the middle of grilling
season the timing is perfect to try this
version with shrimp and by the way this
shrimp Louie reminds me of an old
kitchen joke that I will have to clean
up a little bit but it basically goes
something like this no one ever got you
know what serve in a salad but they were
not including a grilled shrimp Louie
this is the kind of thing that can
definitely get you lots of compliments
okay so I really do hope you give this a
try soon head over to food wishes comm
for all the ingredient amounts have more
info as usual and as always enjoy
